stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the three-hour session inside Course 11 (Oily Boily Bay) underground, polishing gameplay and visuals: fixing bugs, adding a slide entrance, building variable-speed hydraulic platforms, planning a boiling-oil hazard, and revising textures within N64 memory limits. He also reviews progress across earlier levels and discusses overall project status, tools, and post-release plans.
level: General bug-fix pass across all finished courses

development_findings.summary: RTYI now has 15 planned main courses; development is ~75-80 % complete with engine work largely finished.
development_findings.quote: This is course 11… so we are at least two thirds done. Maybe 80 %.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has met 14 consecutive self-imposed daily deadlines and is currently on a ‘bug-fix + Course 11 block-out’ milestone.
development_findings.quote: I’ve done this for 14 days now and so far I hit every single deadline.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 underground gains new gameplay features: a one-way slide entrance and multiple independent hydraulic piston platforms with variable speed and no synced rhythm.
development_findings.quote: This will be Pistonville… I want the rhythm to not sync up at all.

development_findings.summary: A new ‘Chompy’ enemy model and two additional action states are implemented, with a 1-in-16 random trigger.
development_findings.quote: He jumped the hoop… he has a new model too.

development_findings.summary: Oily Boily Bay will include boiling oil that behaves like reflective black tar with bubble particles; Mario can surf it but escaping is hard.
development_findings.quote: Very reflective black tar boiling… add bubbles and some smoke.

development_findings.summary: Strict N64 RAM limits force ‘cursed’ texture resolutions (e.g., 96×42) and careful material merging; Fast64 is used to monitor 4 KB texture slots.
development_findings.quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I’ve ever seen, but it works.

development_findings.summary: Quaternion-based animation exporter (by Lilaa) is a critical dependency; until it arrives, door and warp animations stay broken.
development_findings.quote: Until we have Lilaa’s quaternion animations… we cannot fix the doors.

development_findings.summary: 30 FPS mode optimisation: future plan to merge render & gameplay threads to eliminate reported ‘lag’ and improve speed-runner experience.
development_findings.quote: If you are in 30 FPS mode… the rendering thread goes into the gameplay thread.

development_findings.summary: Engine source will be made public; Kaze doubts anyone will create a true PC port but expects other hackers to adopt the engine.
development_findings.quote: I will make a public source, but I seriously doubt anyone will have the skill to make a PC port.

development_findings.summary: After RTYI ships, Kaze intends to launch a Kickstarter-funded Unreal Engine platformer; a demo will be built before RTYI’s release and the campaigns will run simultaneously.
development_findings.quote: We’re gonna finish a little demo in Unreal Engine and start a Kickstarter simultaneously with the release of RTYI.

development_findings.summary: Design philosophy: difficulty rises by increasing ‘how cool a jump has to be’, not by artificial obstacles; death returns player to hub to retain impact.
development_findings.quote: I don’t make difficulty for the sake of difficulty; I want a cool jump here.

development_findings.summary: Game boots directly into a 3D file-select area (Sunshine-style) to avoid wasting player time.
development_findings.quote: The game boots you directly into the file select. The game doesn’t waste your time.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes modern game design, calling it ‘made for people that are depressed and just want to erase time’.
context_findings.quote: Modern game design is made for people that are depressed and just want to erase time.

context_findings.summary: He maintains daily personal deadlines and claims zero recent ‘slacking’, showing a disciplined work style.
Holds a full-time programming job at Gears for Breakfast while developing RTYI in spare time.
context_findings.quote: I’m a programmer for a living. I work at Gears for Breakfast.

context_findings.summary: Relies on YouTube income; Christmas ad season and potential Honkai Star Rail sponsorship (≈$3 – 4 k) are important funding boosts.
context_findings.quote: Around Christmas the ad revenue is so high… Honkai Star Rail wrote me; that could be $3,000–$4,000.

context_findings.summary: Feels conflicted about producing ‘high-effort’ videos; prefers low-stakes content on second channel and even considers returning to meme posts.
context_findings.quote: Maybe I should just go back to shitposts instead of making decent videos.

context_findings.summary: Expresses strong opinions on controllers (prefers 2-zone dead zone) and run buttons (‘Boo! run buttons!’).
Shows playful but morbid humour (running gag that contributor Lilaa ‘died’).

biobak.summary: Provides high-resolution sail texture and Blender files; collaborates with Kaze to fit them into N64 limits, agreeing on 96×42 I-4 texture.
biobak.quote: Does this work for you, Biobak? 96×42 texture—the most cursed resolution I’ve ever seen.

biobak.summary: Sends additional model parts (ship’s sail) and discusses combining two 64×64 I-4 textures to stay within a 4 KB slot.

badub.summary: Composer (not named on-stream) will be paid for full rights so RTYI’s soundtrack can be released as a standalone N64-cartridge ‘album’.
badub.quote: When RTYI releases, I want to pay the musician to have the rights to the music and then release an album.

zeina.summary: Active in chat, confirms memories of the lost ‘Hot Tub Mario’ mod and participates in humour.

key_stories.title: Lilaa’s ‘Death’ and the Quaternion Exporter
key_stories.summary: Contributor Lilaa vanished from Discord for a week, halting delivery of the quaternion animation exporter. The team jokingly held a ‘funeral’ on-stream, highlighting both dependency pressure and the group’s dark humour.
key_stories.challenge: Exporter is needed to fix door/warp animation glitches; Lilaa is unresponsive.
key_stories.process: Kaze and chat joke about RIP Lilaa, post mock gravestone images, speculate on her status.
key_stories.outcome: Exporter still pending; issue remains open.
key_stories.key_quote: If Lilaa disappears before finishing the quaternion animations I will be so sad.

key_stories.title: The Cursed 96×42 Sail Texture
key_stories.summary: Biobak submits a ship sail that blows past N64 texture memory. Kaze mathematically squeezes it into a bizarre 96×42 I-4 format, illustrating constant technical trade-offs.
key_stories.challenge: 4 KB per-texture RAM ceiling on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Calculate divisors of 4096, test Fast64 memory usage, experiment with unusual dimensions.
key_stories.outcome: Texture loads without overflow; decision logged for in-game verification.

key_stories.title: Kickstarter Pivot
key_stories.summary: Facing future financial uncertainty, Kaze outlines a plan to launch a new Unreal Engine platformer via Kickstarter right when RTYI ships.
key_stories.challenge: Need sustainable income beyond ROM-hack donations and ad revenue.
key_stories.process: Build small Unreal demo before RTYI release; leverage RTYI publicity to boost campaign.
key_stories.outcome: Strategy agreed in principle; details kept private for now.
key_stories.key_quote: Then we will make big money and be able to make whatever we want.
